Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"HESC1501 - Introductory Exercise Science","description":"

This course presents an overview of the vocational activities within the allied health profession of Exercise Physiology. The sub-disciplines of exercise science (exercise physiology, biomechanics, motor control and exercise psychology), and related biomedical sciences, are introduced through examining how the body responds to physical activity. This course includes a clinical practicum component in the University's Lifestyle Clinic. This course is restricted to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Exercise Physiology 3871.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1ada7f9ddb58241055a93324f39619d1","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"CLINICAL EXPERIENCE REPORT","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will report on the clinical activities observed during visits to an exercise physiology clinic (clinical sessions are conducted in the UNSW Medicine Lifestyle Clinic). Students will briefly and clearly report on their clinical observation experience including the process of identifying initial medical conditions, key data from initial assessments, design of exercise programming, movement analysis and professional conduct considerations (in line with the Exercise and Sports Science Australia (ESSA) Code of Conduct)). They will also be required to locate and summarise a journal article that addresses the scientific basis of exercise prescription for a selected clinical condition.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"12da7f9ddb58241055a93324f39619d4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"16da7f9ddb58241055a93324f39619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1ada7f9ddb58241055a93324f39619d3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1ada7f9ddb58241055a93324f39619d6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"SYNOPSIS LABORATORY REPORT","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Student will independently summarise the purpose, methods, results and conclusions from the laboratory conducted on Reaction time and motor learning. They will be required to include with this summary a reference to a relevant journal article.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1ada7f9ddb58241055a93324f39619d3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a2dabf9ddb58241055a93324f3961933","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"ONLINE QUIZZES","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

There will be 5 online quizzes throughout the term. Completing each online activity will earn 2% of the course grade, for a total of 10% for completing all tasks. Marks are awarded once you have attained 80% correct on the quiz, however you can do the quiz as many times as you wish. The online activities are designed to reinforce concepts and skills covered in the lectures.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"12da7f9ddb58241055a93324f39619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"12da7f9ddb58241055a93324f39619d4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1ada7f9ddb58241055a93324f39619d4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e2dabf9ddb58241055a93324f3961922","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"END OF SESSION EXAMINATION","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"50","description":"

The purpose of the exam is to test understanding of the concepts covered in the ENTIRE COURSE. The format will be multiple choice, short answer and long answer questions. The exam will be held during the end of session exam period.

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"HESC1511 - Exercise Programs and Behaviour","description":"

This course will introduce students to the literature examining the effects of physical activity on health and the principles of exercise programming for apparently health populations. Practical training in this course will encompass: fitness assessments, basic pre-screening and interview techniques, and exercise technique and prescription. Psychological aspects of exercise, in particular motivation, adherence and addiction, will also be addressed. These skills will be put into practice with students developing and delivering a supervised exercise program for a healthy adult. This course is restricted to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Exercise Physiology 3871.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5bce89f7dbb91c50eb6b147a3a96198a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Exercise program","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"45","description":"

This assessment will require students to choose a partner from their clinical group to be their client. Students will take their client through an exercise program and write a report evaluating its effectiveness. The assessment wil require students to  1) conduct an interview to determine the client’s goals in relation to lifestyle change; 2) perform a pre-screen and risk stratification to determine the client’s suitability for exercise; 3) conduct basic health and fitness assessments to determine the client’s health status and appropriate starting point for an exercise program and 4) deliver a training session. Competencies across these four components will be assessed and individual feedback will be provided.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"03ce89f7dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961984","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4bce89f7dbb91c50eb6b147a3a96197b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"87ce89f7dbb91c50eb6b147a3a96197e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c3ce89f7dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961981","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"32ce89f7dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961969","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group exercise program","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

This assessment will require students to work together in small groups to develop an exercise session for a group of healthy participants of their choosing (e.g. sports team, school class). The assessment will have a written and a practical component. For the written component, students will be asked to submit a written planning document that outlines the exercise session for their target population. A group mark will be awarded for this section. For the practical component, students will be required to take their classmates through a portion of their planned exercise session. This will be done during laboratory times. Students will share the delivery of the exercise session by taking turns in individually instructing different sections of a 45-60 minute session.  An individual mark will be awarded for this section. Written feedback will be provided for the written component and verbal and written feedback will be provided for the practical component. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"4fce89f7dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961986","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7ace89f7dbb91c50eb6b147a3a96196d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"35","description":"

The final exam will be a written exam designed to assess the student’s understanding of the concepts covered in the entire course. The format will be multiple choice and short answers. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"03ce89f7dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961984","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4bce89f7dbb91c50eb6b147a3a96197b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"4fce89f7dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961986","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"87ce89f7dbb91c50eb6b147a3a96197e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b2ce89f7dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961972","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Diet analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

This is a summative assessment and will consist of 20 multiple choice questions relating to diet analysis and nutrition content taught in the course. Feedback will be provided in the form of a grade and general feedback to the cohort.

contentlets.keywords: health and exercise science,exercise physiology,exercise science,health
contentlets.description: This course will introduce students to the literature examining the effects of physical activity on health and the principles of exercise programming for apparently health populations. Practical training in this course will encompass: fitness assessments, basic pre-screening and interview techniques, and exercise technique and prescription. Psychological aspects of exercise, in particular motivation, adherence and addiction, will also be addressed. These skills will be put into practice with students developing and delivering a supervised exercise program for a healthy adult. This course is restricted to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Exercise Physiology 3871.
contentlets.title: Exercise Programs and Behaviour

Students will study the basic principles of biomechanics and apply these to the analysis of human movement and the musculoskeletal system. Basic mechanics (statics, kinematics and dynamics) will be studied in two dimensions. The biomechanics of walking, running and jumping will be studied. This will integrate the student's understanding of mechanics with functional anatomy through the study of normal gait dynamics, musculoskeletal function, work and power. The mechanics of tissues in the musculoskeletal system will be introduced. Methods for assessing movement, quantitative and qualitative, will be covered.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1ae1c825db98241055a93324f396193c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Tests","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will take two written Tests throughout the term (worth 10% each). Assessment content will include lectures and laboratories. Similar to the format of the final exam, Tests provide an opportunity for students to apply their knowledge and problem-solving skills to answer calculation-based questions. A grade will be provided for each question and specific written feedback will be included where applicable.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"92e1c825db98241055a93324f396193f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9ae1c825db98241055a93324f396193e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9ae1c825db98241055a93324f396193f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9ee1c825db98241055a93324f396193d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"22e1c825db98241055a93324f396194a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":" Lab Assessments","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

The laboratory classes provide an opportunity for students to apply their theoretical knowledge of biomechanics to a practical scenario. By conducting lab-based experiments in small groups, students also gain experience in collecting, processing and analysing data.

The Laboratory Assessments are individual student submissions. They require students to present and discuss their findings from a small sample of lab classes (e.g., Assessment I will cover content from classes 1-2). Students will receive feedback in the form of a grading rubric, with additional comments provided where applicable.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"92e1c825db98241055a93324f396193f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9ae1c825db98241055a93324f396193e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9ae1c825db98241055a93324f396193f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9ee1c825db98241055a93324f396193d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6ae1c825db98241055a93324f396194f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

The written Exam will be undertaken during the UNSW exam period. All course content can be assessed.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"92e1c825db98241055a93324f396193f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9ae1c825db98241055a93324f396193e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9ae1c825db98241055a93324f396193f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9ee1c825db98241055a93324f396193d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a2e1c825db98241055a93324f3961955","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Weekly Progress Marks","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

The Weekly Progress Marks are designed to encourage students to engage with the lecture modules in Moodle. They ensure students progress through the course in a timely manner. Scoring 85%+ on the short quizzes integrated into the lectures (for which multiple attempts are facilitated), and completing the relevant lectures by the weekly deadline, will result in a student receiving a proportion of the total 10% grade available (e.g., for nine weeks of lecture content, each week's Progress Mark will be worth 1.11%). Failure to meet these requirements will result in a student receiving 0% for a given week.

Online quizzes are dispersed throughout the modules, and content includes key concepts of the lecture. Feedback on questions is generated automatically and provided instantaneously to students.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"HESC2452","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"HESC2452 - Movement Assessment and Instruction","description":"

This course will equip you with knowledge and skills for assessing and instructing clients and patients in exercises and other movements. You will integrate concepts from biomechanics, functional anatomy, motor learning and skill acquisition in the analysis of exercises, work tasks and activities of daily living. You will apply your theoretical understanding of biomechanics and functional anatomy in practical analysis of movement, using both quantitative and qualitative approaches. The course will also cover aspects of exercise instruction and approaches to movement education. You will develop practical skills in teaching new or modified exercises, work tasks or activities of daily living, giving consideration to pedagogical theory in relation to instructing clients and patients regarding movement and exercise.


This course is restricted to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Exercise Physiology 3871.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f7bed6b8db503c50be4672f5f3961946","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"End of semester exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"35","description":"

Students are to undertake a written examination comprised of questions targeted at assessing student’s knowledge and practical application of key concepts covered in the course, including lectures, laboratories and tutorials. The examination will consist of multiple choice and short answer questions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f3bed6b8db503c50be4672f5f3961947","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f7bed6b8db503c50be4672f5f3961949","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"ffbed6b8db503c50be4672f5f3961947","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ffbed6b8db503c50be4672f5f3961948","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0cced6b8db503c50be4672f5f3961955","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Movement Instruction Skills Assessment","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

This practical assessment task will assess students’ ability to perform movement instruction and qualitative analysis of commonly used exercises by Exercise Physiologists. This assessment requires completion of two parts:

Part A) Movement Instruction Video & Peer Assessment (15%) due Week 8 –  Students are required to submit a short video of themselves instructing one exercise to a friend/housemate/partner/family member etc. Students will then assess two peer video submissions, using a marking rubric and calibration tool. Peer assessment will be randomly allocated, and is compulsory in order to obtain a mark for Part A. Feedback provided from Part A should be used in preparation for Part B.

Part B) Live Movement Instruction and Qualitative Analysis (10%). Final Exam Period – Students are required to conduct a movement instruction session with a mock patient. Mock patients will be allocated by the course convenors. Students will be required to instruct two exercises in real-time in a face-to-face setting on campus. Students will be assessed on their use of physical demonstration, verbal instruction, feedback delivery, and motivational strategies. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f7bed6b8db503c50be4672f5f3961948","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f7bed6b8db503c50be4672f5f3961949","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ffbed6b8db503c50be4672f5f3961948","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"33bed6b8db503c50be4672f5f3961951","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Quantitative Motion Analysis Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

This is a group assessment task conducted in the form of a multi-stage movement analysis project. Students will use quantitative motion analysis and/or electromyography (EMG) techniques to collect quantitative movement data. They will then process (calculate kinematic data using specialised motion analysis software), analyse and interpret the data to answer a specific research question. The project will be conducted in small groups, with each group working collaboratively to plan and conduct their quantitative motion analysis project. Students will be assessed on two separate components.

Part A) Proposal (10%) – Each group will be required to submit a 1-2 page page written project proposal including  i) summary of the research question, ii) description of the movement to be analysed, iii) description of data collection methodology; iv) summary of variables that will be processed, analysed and interpreted.

Part B) Presentation (15%) – Students will give a group oral presentation on their research project. This will include background, aims, methods, results and discussion (including limitations). Each group’s presentation will be 12-15 minutes in duration.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f3bed6b8db503c50be4672f5f3961947","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"ffbed6b8db503c50be4672f5f3961947","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"84ced6b8db503c50be4672f5f396195b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Laboratory submissions","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Laboratory work for three laboratory classes will contribute to 15% of the course result, 5% per lab. For each lab, assessment is based on processing, graphical presentation and interpretation of quantitative motion analysis data. Assessment items must be submitted within one (1) week after the laboratory session in which the work is completed. Written feedback will be provided based on the marking rubric.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f3bed6b8db503c50be4672f5f3961947","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"ffbed6b8db503c50be4672f5f3961947","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b7bed6b8db503c50be4672f5f396194b","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/HESC2452.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"HESC2501","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"HESC2501 - Exercise Physiology","description":"

In this course you will develop detailed understanding and practical application of the physiological adaptations of the respiratory, cardiovascular, endocrine and musculoskeletal systems to acute and chronic exercise. Specific adaptations to the different components of exercise (intensity, duration, type) will be explored. Practical skills and techniques used to monitor and analyse those adaptations will be developed throughout this course e.g. submaximal and maximal exercise tests, ECG, spirometry.   


This course is restricted to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Exercise Physiology 3871.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a2b455f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619cc","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory reports","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Students submit lab reports based on data obtained from specific labs over the course. Part 1 is worth 7% and will be completed in the early laboratory classes as a lead up to Part 2. Part is the main lab report worth 18%, totalling 25% overall for this assessment task. Part 1 will be assessed in the Lab classes and Part 2 is to be submitted via Moodle. Students are given feedback in class for Part 1 and will be given feedback within 10 working days on Part 2. The marking rubric is detailed in the course outline.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a2b455f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619bd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a6b455f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"eeb455f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619bf","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"16b455f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961974","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Objective structured clinical examination (OSCE)","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

The OSCE will be held during the exam period. It will assess student’s ability to perform practical skills commonly applied in clinical exercise physiology, as learnt during the laboratories. The assessment environment aims to simulate clinical scenarios. Each student will be required to perform a range of competencies under the supervision of an examiner. Students will be assessed on communication, technical and procedural skills.  Students who do not achieve the 70% pass mark, may be required to attend an intensive workshop and sit a supplementary exam. Students will receive written feedback within 5 working days. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2eb455f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619c2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6ab455f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a2b455f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619bd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"16b455f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961996","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Progress quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

There are several progress quizzes throughout the course, comprised of short answer questions, multiple choice and/or short calculations. The questions will be based on the material covered in the lectures, practical classes and tutorials. This will assess students understanding and application of the concepts developed in the course. The tests will be held in conjunction with their tutorial classes. Please see the course schedule for the specific dates. Students will receive written feedback immediately after. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a2b455f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619bd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"eeb455f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619bf","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5eb455f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961978","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"35","description":"

The end of session exam is a written exam comprised of multiple choice and short answer questions, and analytical interpretation of clinical assessment. It will be held during the examination period, and will cover all lecture (including online), tutorial and laboratory content. Feedback will be available on student request.

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"HESC3501 - Advanced Exercise Science","description":"

The focus of this course is on advanced understanding of exercise prescription, delivery and testing among apparently healthy and sporting populations. It covers the areas of exercise science, functional anatomy and motor learning, including strength and conditioning, agility training and skill development. This course offers a mixture of traditional and interactive/ hands-on approaches to learning and teaching.


Skills and techniques performed by Accredited Exercise Scientists & Accredited Exercise Physiologists (AES & AEP’s) in the sector of apparently healthy and elite populations will be developed in this course. Students will also complete 40 hours of Exercise Science clinical practicum hours throughout this course. This practicum experience is developed under the supervision of AES’s, AEP’s or other suitably qualified health professionals.


This course is restricted to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Exercise Physiology 3871.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e5a06329db72a45055a93324f396194b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Individual assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This is an individual written assignment.  Students will be provided with case studies in order to write an individual exercise program.  This assessment will be due at the end of week 5 prior to flexibility week.  The students will be able to utilise the feedback provided in order to improve on their following group periodised plan assessment.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e5a06329db72a45055a93324f396194c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"eda06329db72a45055a93324f396194c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"75a06329db72a45055a93324f396195b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Practical skills portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

This portfolio requires students’ successful completion of  practical skills demonstrations. This is made up of industry standard skills which students will develop throughout the practical components of this course. This will be assessed by tutors in the laboratories  across the Term.  This section of the portfolio is worth 20% (2x10%).  This is a hurdle item and students must achieve an average of 70% across the two assessments to pass the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e5a06329db72a45055a93324f396194d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"eda06329db72a45055a93324f396194d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7da06329db72a45055a93324f396195e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Practical VIVA exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

This is a practical exam, performed individually by each student. Each student is given a random/ unknown skills test to research 2 weeks prior to the exam date. On the exam date, they are required to perform the appropriate practical skills (exercise testing and communication) and justify the use of the test in front of an examiner. Students will receive feedback via an online app shortly after the viva. This assessment will be held during the university final exam period. This is a mastery assessment for the course (70% pass mark)

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e5a06329db72a45055a93324f396194c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e5a06329db72a45055a93324f396194d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"eda06329db72a45055a93324f396194d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ada06329db72a45055a93324f396194f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Prescription / periodisation write ups for clients","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

In this group assignment, students will work as a group to write up an exercise prescription/ periodisation plan. The prescription will be specific to apparently healthy’ clients that come to UNSW for assessments and exercise prescriptions. Students will be required to compile and evaluate the data their group has collected during the allocated Practicum hours on the above-mentioned clients. These findings and a prescription write-up will be completed as a group. The prescription will follow evidence-based practice on appropriate exercise prescription and periodisation guidelines for this population.

\n

 

\n

This assessment will have a maximum word limit of 2000 words. This assessment will be due in week 10.

contentlets.description:
The focus of this course is on advanced understanding of exercise prescription, delivery and testing among apparently healthy and sporting populations. It covers the areas of exercise science, functional anatomy and motor learning, including strength and conditioning, agility training and skill development. This course offers a mixture of traditional and interactive/ hands-on approaches to learning and teaching.

Skills and techniques performed by Accredited Exercise Scientists & Accredited Exercise Physiologists (AES & AEP’s) in the sector of apparently healthy and elite populations will be developed in this course. Students will also complete 40 hours of Exercise Science clinical practicum hours throughout this course. This practicum experience is developed under the supervision of AES’s, AEP’s or other suitably qualified health professionals.

This course is restricted to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Exercise Physiology 3871.

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"HESC3504 - Physical Activity and Health","description":"

The focus of this course is on the effects of exercise on apparently healthy populations and those with increased cardiovascular risk across the lifespan. Psychological aspects of exercise, including the application of behaviour change and self-management strategies, comprise a significant component of this course. The literature addressing the impact of physical activity on cardiovascular risk reduction and the prevention of disease will be discussed in detail through examining the mechanisms by which exercise alters metabolic, vascular, muscular and cognitive function, both chronically and acutely. Health-based screening and intervention techniques (including basic nutrition assessments) will be applied with students undertaking a supervised lifestyle change project. 


This course is restricted to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Exercise Physiology 3871.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"d574c2ebdb759850eb6b147a3a96193d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Lifestyle Change Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

  • Students will plan and implement a Lifestyle Change Project based on the individual needs of an apparently healthy adult client. Clients who are deemed moderate cardiovascular risk, maybe permitted after discussion with the course convenor. This permission to participate will depend on the potential participant’s risk factors.  

  • The project includes two phases of assessment (a) a clinical skills assessment and (b) a written report. Feedback and fine tuning of the project will be ongoing and provided throughout the semester in the lab classes by the AEP (Accredited Exercise Physiologist) teaching the class.   

  • This project will give students 40 hours toward ESSA Exercise Physiology Accreditation.

Phase A: Clinical Skills Assessment (10%)           

Students will be graded on exercise training and assessment skills. Two types of skills will be assessed: 

  1. Skills in training the client (supervising, motivating, monitoring, exercise execution, exercise appropriateness, progressions and communication) Marks allocated to this assessment are 5%. 

  1. Skills in performing client’s final fitness assessment (choice, administration and execution of tests, monitoring, organisation and professionalism). Marks allocated to this assessment are 5%. 

Phase B: Written Report (25%)    

Students will compile a client file and write a short reflection on how they feel the project went for their client. This reflection should justify the exercise prescription and reflect on how things may have been done differently. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5d74c2ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961924","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9974c2ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961927","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d574c2ebdb759850eb6b147a3a96192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d974c2ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961939","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0174c2ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961903","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Behaviour Change Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

This assignment is designed to allow the student the opportunity to practice the challenging task of changing a client’s behaviour. Students will Identify a problematic health or physical activity behaviour for their client in the Lifestyle Change Project. They will then develop a specific plan for the client to help them change that problematic health or physical activity behaviour for the better. The approach taken to changing the client’s behaviour should be based on one or more of the psychological theories/models of behaviour change learnt in class. Student will help the client to implement the behavioural change plan and monitor the client’s progress along the way. Students will write up and submit a report detailing the experience.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1174c2ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9974c2ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961927","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d974c2ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961939","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4974c2ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961907","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"35","description":"

The end of session examination will test student’s knowledge of physical activity and health and also their ability to apply the knowledge they have acquired from the course material to client management. The questions will be based on the material covered in the lectures and practical classes and the prescribed readings over the entire semester. Feedback is provided upon request of student. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1174c2ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5d74c2ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961924","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9974c2ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961927","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d574c2ebdb759850eb6b147a3a96192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d974c2ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961939","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8174c2ebdb759850eb6b147a3a96190c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online quizzes and Case Study","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

  • The quizzes will be conducted each week and will test student’s understanding and practical application of course concepts. The format will be multiple choice questions. In total the 9 quizzes during weeks 1 to 9 are worth 5% towards the final grade.  

  • In Week 10, students will be provided with a link to an online case study on a patient with metabolic syndrome. Results from this case study will contribute to 5% of the overall mark.  

  • Feedback on results of each question in the quiz will be provided immediately to the student upon answering the question.

The work of the Exercise Physiologist is underpinned by psychological theories of human behaviour. Understanding these principles and learning how to apply them to work with clients leads to improved practice. Health, Exercise and Sport Psychology builds on the content covered in stages 1 and 2 of the Exercise Physiology Program. It provides advanced understanding of contemporary psychological theories so that students are equipped with the knowledge and skills required to work optimally with individuals in health, exercise and sports across the lifespan.


This course is restricted to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Exercise Physiology 3871.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"49e2c0a5db98241055a93324f39619a3","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Theory Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

This is a closed book final 2 hour exam to be completed individually be each student. This assessment will be completed in the University exam period. This exam will assess knowledge of psychological theories of physical activity, exercise and sports. Assessment will be combination of multiple choice and short answer.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"01e2c0a5db98241055a93324f39619a4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"09e2c0a5db98241055a93324f39619a5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0de204a5db98241055a93324f3961929","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Communication Skills","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Students are required to act as an Exercise Physiologist and conduct an assessment using communication skills as part of a behaviour change intervention to elicit a change in health behaviour. This will be assessed by a staff member during the lab in week 10.

The quizzes will be completed throughout the semester. They will test student’s knowledge on psychological theories of human behaviour, motivation and psychological assessment; and knowledge of sports psychology respectively. The format will be multiple choice online. Feedback will be provided to students.

This course expores the use of evidence-based exercise interventions in the treatment and management of a wide range of musculoskeletal pain conditions. The emphasis is on developing student competency with assessment and exercise prescription for chronic musculoskeletal conditions consistent with a biopsychosocial treatment approach. Considerable attention is given to developing clinical reasoning and skills and the translation of theoretical knowledge to clinical practice to prepare students for professional practice in musculoskeletal rehabilitation. This will be achieved through student centred teaching and learning modalities including team-based learning, clinical laboratories, flipped classrooms and online learning activities.  This course also provides students opportunity to further develop their knowledge and skills with musculoskeletal rehabilitation prior to commencing clinical practicum.

The final exam comprises of multiple choice and short answer questions assessing students’ understanding and practical application of key concepts covered in the course across the course. No indivdualised feedback will be provided. Exam to be completed within the exam period.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0970513fdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961927","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"0d70513fdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4570513fdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"4970513fdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961935","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8170513fdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96192d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3870513fdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961919","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Skills assessment (viva)","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

Conducted in the exam period. The viva assesses the practical application of the knowledge and skills covered in the course and involves a 40 minute oral and skills assessment specific to exercise physiology clinical practice in musculoskeletal rehabilitation. The oral assessment involves verbal responses to questions posed by the examiner. The clinical skills demonstration requires the student to perform a physical assessment or exercise prescription technique commonly used by exercise physiologists in musculoskeletal rehabilitation. Before commencing the assessment, students will be given 15 minutes to read their case and consider the specific questions and skills that will to be assessed. The marking rubric for the viva is detailed in the course outline. There are 3 academic markers who will provide verbal feedback to the students immediately following the viva. This assessment is a hurdle requirment for completing this course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0970513fdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961927","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"0d70513fdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4570513fdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"4970513fdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961935","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8170513fdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96192d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"cd70513fdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96192f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7070513fdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96191e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Team-based learning (TBL) tutorial","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Team-based learning (TBL) tutorials will be held 3 times during the term. Students will be required to actively participate (through poster presentation, oral contribution and class discussion) as a group during this in-class tutorial. Understanding of the pre-learning material will be assessed at the start of each TBL through a 10-question multiple choice quiz. Students will first complete this quiz an an individual, and then complete the same quiz as a group. Marks for individual contribution during each TBL will be allocated through peer assessment. Each TBL tutorial will be weighted to 10% for a total course contribution of 30%. Individualised feedback is provided to all students within 10 business days.

The case study exam involves short answer questions assessing the students’ understanding and practical application of key concepts covered in the course during weeks 1-4 inclusive. Individualised feedback is provided to all students within 10 business days.

This course will provide you information about the epidemiology and the pathophysiology of respiratory, metabolic, cardiovascular and immune diseases. You will gain knowledge of how to set up and implement exercise testing and programming in these special populations in order to provide symptomatic relief, as well as to manage the underlying disease. You will also learn how to manage the interaction between exercise and medications in these special populations. By the end of the semester you will be able to successfully use exercise testing and programming in individuals with these diseases to improve their health and quality of life. The teaching and learning approaches used in this course will include problem-based learning as well as more traditional evidence-based information provided during the lectures. 


This course is restricted to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Exercise Physiology 3871.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e26442ebdb759850eb6b147a3a96191d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

The laboratory report is designed to assess students’ competency in key aspects of exercise testing and prescription including pre-exercise screening, designing and conducting an exercise test, and interpreting the results of the exercise test. Formative feedback will be provided to students through comments made on their report (done through the marking rubric on TurnItIn). Summative feedback will also be provided to student in the form of a grade for the report.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5e6442ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9a6442ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961916","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d66442ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961919","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"026442ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961903","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

The final exam consists of short answer questions designed to assess students’ knowledge of content covered in lectures, laboratories and tutorials. Questions are designed to test students’ factual knowledge of the pathophysiology of various diseases and their ability to apply clinical reasoning to analyse and interpret data from exercise testing, with greater emphasis placed on the latter. Students are provided with the opportunity to examine their exam paper with the lecturer (formative feedback) once marks have been released (summative feedback). 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"126442ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961911","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5e6442ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d66442ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961919","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4a6442ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961907","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid Semester Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

The mid-semester exam consists of short answer questions designed to assess students’ knowledge of content covered in lectures, laboratories and tutorials. Questions are designed to test students’ factual knowledge of the pathophysiology of various diseases and the effects of exercise on these diseases. Questions also assess students’ ability to apply clinical reasoning to analyse and interpret data from exercise testing. Formative feedback is provided to students during the next lecture when the lecturer will discuss the correct answers. Students are also provided with the opportunity to examine their exam paper once the marks for the exam have been released (i.e. summative feedback).  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"126442ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961911","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5e6442ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d66442ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961919","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8e6402ebdb759850eb6b147a3a9619f9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Clinical Skills Assessment","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Students will be tested on their ability to perform one of the primary practical skills they learn during the laboratories. This will be done during an exercise test in their scheduled laboratory time. Students will be assessed on their communication, procedural and technical abilities for the relevant skill. Formative feedback will be provided to each student at the end of the class through verbal feedback from the demonstrator. Students are also provided with the opportunity to review their performance with the demonstrator at a later stage. Summative feedback will also be provided to student in the form of a grade for the task.

contentlets.description:
This course will provide you information about the epidemiology and the pathophysiology of respiratory, metabolic, cardiovascular and immune diseases. You will gain knowledge of how to set up and implement exercise testing and programming in these special populations in order to provide symptomatic relief, as well as to manage the underlying disease. You will also learn how to manage the interaction between exercise and medications in these special populations. By the end of the semester you will be able to successfully use exercise testing and programming in individuals with these diseases to improve their health and quality of life. The teaching and learning approaches used in this course will include problem-based learning as well as more traditional evidence-based information provided during the lectures. 

This course is restricted to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Exercise Physiology 3871.

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"HESC3581 - Exercise Prescription in Diverse Populations","description":"

This course focuses on the role of engaging diverse populations in physical activity and exercise. Students are provided with the opportunity to develop an understanding of specific needs for engaging in physical activity, including specific limitations, considerations, individualisation of testing and training procedures. This course examines current literature regarding the impact of physical activity on the health status of a diverse range of populations. Target conditions covered in this course include children, corporate health, women’s health issues (menopause, pregnancy, gestational diabetes) and indigenous populations; as well as people with cancer, chronic kidney disease, mental health disorders, and sleep disorders. This course offers a mixture of traditional and interactive (case study) approaches to learning. Lectures will build on material presented in HESC3504 (Physical Activity and Health) and HESC3541 (Clinical Exercise Physiology) and in-depth knowledge on these diverse populations will be provided.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"89aaa278db903c50be4672f5f39619b9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Exercise prescription write-ups","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

Two prescription write-ups will be required. There will be a 1,000 word limit for each prescription not including figures, diagrams and references. The first write up will be on the effects of exercise on health outcomes of a specified population. A choice of scenarios will be provided for the second write-up based on one of the diverse populations relevant to the course content.

This assessment task will be held during the final examination period, and will cover all material presented in lectures and tutorials from the entire term. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"81aaa278db903c50be4672f5f39619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"85aaa278db903c50be4672f5f39619ba","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"89aaa278db903c50be4672f5f39619bb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"49aa2678db903c50be4672f5f3961977","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"e-Portfolio Reflections","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

In this assessment task, students will reflect on and evaluate the different aspects of the role of Exercise Physiologists in TWO of the diverse populations covered in this course. Students will submit a concise reflection on the role of Exercise Physiologists, other health professionals, and their own practical professional experience, for delivering research based multidisciplinary care for effective lifestyle management. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"81aaa278db903c50be4672f5f39619bb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"81aaa278db903c50be4672f5f39619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"cdaa2678db903c50be4672f5f396196f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"59aa2678db903c50be4672f5f3961988","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Online Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Students will complete 4 short online quizzes throughout the term. These quizzes are an individual task in which students will answer multiple choice questions based on the lecture and tutorial content covered in in the preceding weeks. Feedback will be provided at the close of the assessment task.

This course provides the opportunity for students to understand the potential, and limitations, of exercise as a tool for clinical rehabilitation in patients with neurological disorders. Specific information about a range of neuromuscular disorders is provided, and students are encouraged to apply their knowledge to case studies and scenarios in order to develop the scientific and clinical attributes necessary to contribute effectively to a neuromuscular rehabilitation team. This course offers a mixture of traditional and interactive/case study approaches to learning and includes a series of simulated case study learning sessions that emphasise the application of theory to clinical situations. These simulated case study learning sessions are designed as a bridge between the lifestyle change project with an apparently healthy client in HESC3504 and the year 4 clinical practicum courses in the workplace. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"02f35577dbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619c4","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Simulated Case Study Learning Session (SCSLS)","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

SCSLSwill be held 4 times throughout the semester. On 2 of these occasions, students will contribute to the facilitated case study discussions as part of a team worth 20% in total. Students will verbally contribute to a clinical discussion on the management of a complex neurorehabilitation case, providing rationale for each of their contirbutions. Each student’s contribution in the class will be assessed by their peers (i.e. the active listeners) and academic staff. The marks will be weighted as followed: academic observers provide a mark for each individual student and a group mark.  The active listeners submit an individual mark, and group mark. Students are provided written feedback. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b1f35577dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96199c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b5f35577dbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f1f35577dbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"21f35577dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961985","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Simulated Case Study Reports: GP report with exercise program","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

They are required to submit 2 written reports which include a letter to the patient’s physician/treating parties in addition to an exercise program written in a suitable form to guide the patient and for clinician record. The marking rubric is detailed in the course outline. Individualised written/audio feedback is provided for all reports and exercise programs. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"31f35577dbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7df35577dbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b1f35577dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96199c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"69f35577dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961989","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Skills assessment (viva)","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

The viva assesses the practical application of the knowledge and skills covered in the course and involves an oral and skills assessment specific to exercise physiology clinical practice in neuromuscular rehabilitation. The oral assessment involves verbal responses to questions posed by the examiner. The clinical skills demonstration requires the student to perform a physical assessment or exercise prescription technique commonly used by exercise physiologists in neuromuscular rehabilitation. Before commencing the assessment, students will be given time to read their case and consider the specific questions and skills that will be assessed. The marking rubric for the viva is detailed in the course outline. There are 3 academic markers who will provide verbal feedback to the students immediately following the viva. Satisfactory completion of the course requires students to pass the viva examination.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"31f35577dbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b1f35577dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96199c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f1f35577dbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a1f35577dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96198e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"End of semester exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

Students undertake a 2-hour exam comprised of questions targeted at assessing student’s knowledge and practical application of key concepts covered in the course. Feedback is provided upon request of student. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7df35577dbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b5f35577dbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f1f35577dbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e9f35577dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961992","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/HESC3592.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"HESC4501","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"HESC4501 - Exercise Physiology Research Seminars","description":"

This course trains students to be able to critically interpret scientific and clinical research linked to the field of exercise physiology to enhance their clinical practice. Students learn the skills necessary to research (find), read, understand and communicate clinical research in the practical sessions and seminars. Assessment tasks provide experience in looking up original research articles, appraising their value and communicating this to colleagues and the general public via an oral or poster presentation. Assessment tasks will also teach students to work in a team environment. 


This course is restricted to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Exercise Physiology 3871.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"008446ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961909","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Paper Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will work independently to select an original journal article (not a review) related to the field of Exercise Science or Exercise Physiology. Students will present the main findings, draw conclusions, critique and provide links of the relevance to the Exercise sciences. This will be delivered as an oral presentation, followed by feedback and discussion. Presentation will be marked in class according to a rubric detailed in the course outline.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7b7406ebdb759850eb6b147a3a9619ed","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b77406ebdb759850eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f37406ebdb759850eb6b147a3a9619f3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"237406ebdb759850eb6b147a3a9619ca","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will have their class activity and engagement assessed for 6 tutorial sessions each worth 5%.

Tutorial 1 students read an ESSA position statement and determine if there is research to validate the recommendations; Tutorial 2: students summarise a research article and submit the summary document thru the course Moodle page; Tutorial 4: students give a short 3 minute presentation in class; Tutorials 5, 6 and 11 students complete an online Quiz after this class.

Tasks performed in class will be marked by the tutor and feedback will be given via moodle or face to face

 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"048446ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"337406ebdb759850eb6b147a3a9619f6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7b7406ebdb759850eb6b147a3a9619ed","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b77406ebdb759850eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f37406ebdb759850eb6b147a3a9619f3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6b7406ebdb759850eb6b147a3a9619ce","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Innovation in Exercise Physiology","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

This Assignment has 4 Assessable components Two of which are marked at the individual level (total of 20%) and Two as a group mark (total of 20%). Presentation group mark (Talk 15%, Poster 5%), Peer mark of an Individual on effort and engagement (10%), Completed self-assessment form of effort during task (10%)

As part of a team, students are asked to create a tool, a protocol or a technique with an application to Exercise Science/Physiology. Students will use research to show the gap that the innovation is filling, the feasibility of the innovation and the marketability of the innovation.

The innovation can be to enhance research, or improve patient outcomes, or improve patient (or even society) quality of life.

Students will define the field the innovation is associated with, demonstrate the innovations novelty and demonstrate the feasibility of the innovation. 

Students will present the innovation to the class in their groups as an oral poster presentation, followed by discussion. The presentation will be marked in class and feedback on both the poster and the presentation will be given in class. 

The students will peer assess fellow members effort and contribution (via moodle) and this will modify the mark an individual within the group receives.

The students will also self assess their effort and growth during this assignment to further separate the individual marks each group member receives, feed back given via Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"048446ebdb759850eb6b147a3a961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"337406ebdb759850eb6b147a3a9619f6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7b7406ebdb759850eb6b147a3a9619ed","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b77406ebdb759850eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f37406ebdb759850eb6b147a3a9619f3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a37406ebdb759850eb6b147a3a9619d3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"ePortfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"5","description":"

Students write an ePortfolio of reflection on their learning and experience within the course as well as collating the learning that they have achieved over the semester.

Students submit a 1000-1500 word summary that provides insight into their use of the portfolio (refer to eportfolio assessment rubric in course outline). This will be marked online and feedback will be given by the tutor via Moodle.

contentlets.description:
This course trains students to be able to critically interpret scientific and clinical research linked to the field of exercise physiology to enhance their clinical practice. Students learn the skills necessary to research (find), read, understand and communicate clinical research in the practical sessions and seminars. Assessment tasks provide experience in looking up original research articles, appraising their value and communicating this to colleagues and the general public via an oral or poster presentation. Assessment tasks will also teach students to work in a team environment. 

This course is restricted to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Exercise Physiology 3871.
contentlets.title: Exercise Physiology Research Seminars

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"HESC4502","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"HESC4502 - Workplace Assessment and Rehabilitation","description":"

This course will equip students with the knowledge and skills required for employment opportunities as an Accredited Exercise Physiologist (AEP) within the workplace assessment and rehabilitation sector. After completing this course new graduates will be accredited by the State Insurance Regulatory Authority (SIRA) to provide services to injured workers insured under their scheme. Students are provided with the opportunity to develop competency and understanding of workers compensation systems and SIRA legislative requirements; the epidemiology of occupational injury; occupational health and safety; functional capacity assessment; workplace injury prevention and rehabilitation; exercise interventions in workplace rehabilitation; and report writing and communication with key stakeholders at a professional standard.


This course offers a mixture of online and student-based learning activities (team-based learning), with the emphasise on the application of theoretical knowledge towards AEP professional practice. By completing this unit, students will develop the knowledge and practical skills (required for SIRA accreditation) to assist students transition to provision of AEP services in the area of workplace assessment and injury rehabilitation. SIRA accreditation is an essential criterion for AEPs seeking employment in occupational rehabilitation.


This course is restricted to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Exercise Physiology 3871.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"efb495f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961963","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Team-Based Learning Tutorial Workshop","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Team-based learning (TBL) tutorials will be held 2 times during the semester (week 5 & 10/11). Students will be required to actively participate (through poster presentation, oral contribution and class discussion) as a team during this in-class tutorial. There will be 5 “experts” on the floor to assist students with problem solving and clarifying key concepts during the class. Your understanding of the pre-learning material for the TBL will be assessed at the start of the TBL through a multiple choice quiz which you will first complete as an individual and then as a team. Marks for individual contribution during the TBL will be allocated through self-reflection and peer assessment. Each TBL tutorial will be weighted to 15% for a total contribution of 30%. Your participation, contribution and grading for the TBLs is dependent on your preparation and completion of the pre-learning material. Feedback on each team’s contribution will be provided by the AEP experts on the floor during the TBL.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"53b495f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96193c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a7b495f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96195d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ebb495f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961941","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"07b495f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96191a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be required to complete an individual assessment task based on content delivered in the online learning activities. The assignment will be concerned with AEP professional practice, with the primary objective of preparing students for professional practice. 

This assignment requires completion of two parts:

Part a) Functional Capacity Assessment (FCA) and reporting. Report detailing the findings of an FCA for an injured worker.

Part b) AEP led workplace training. Develop a workplace injury prevention program or individualised exercise program for a specific occupation which may include a workplace exercise program.

The purpose of this exam is to test your recall and understanding of the concepts covered in this course including online learning activities, required readings and team-based learning tutorials. The exam will be held during the end of session exam period.

This quiz is an individual task in which students will answer multiple choice questions, based on practical and theoretical knowledge covered during weeks 1-3 (inclusive). Feedback will be provided at the close of the assessment task.

This course is the first term (10 weeks) of a 20-week supervised research internship based on an individual research project supervised by a member of academic staff. The project may encompass a systematic literature review, resource or project development, or a clinical or laboratory investigation. The project may also involve a ‘placement’, possibly outside UNSW, in research or industry, which may occur outside session. The course will develop your ability to formulate research questions, conduct in-depth studies, analyse and present data, and write reports.


This course is restricted to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Exercise Physiology 3871.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"28d30ce5db98241055a93324f3961962","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Integrity Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Safe and responsible research practices are essential to sustain high quality research.  This assessment item consists of an online quiz designed to help prepare students to undertake a research project. Learning objectives of this assessment task are to:

            • Gain knowledge of the basics of safe research practice

            • Gain knowledge of ethical and responsible research practices

Completed by end of Week 3

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"24d34ce5db98241055a93324f3961906","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"70d34ce5db98241055a93324f3961910","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Protocol","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

A written assignment of 2000 words, detailing the intended research protocol. This includes background information, relevance and importance to exercise physiology, project aims, hypothesis and methods to be used or developed.

Due in Week 9.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"24d34ce5db98241055a93324f3961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"24d34ce5db98241055a93324f3961906","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"24d34ce5db98241055a93324f3961907","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2cd34ce5db98241055a93324f3961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2cd34ce5db98241055a93324f3961906","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"70d34ce5db98241055a93324f3961919","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Oral Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

An oral presentation introducing the topic of the research internship and its importance to exercise physiology. This will include details of background information, research project aims, hypothesis and methods to be used or developed. 

Presented in Week 5. Feedback will be provided after the presentation. Feedback will guide subsequent completion of the Research Protocol assignment.
