","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"HESC4571","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"HESC4571 - Research Internship B","description":"

This course is the second term (10 weeks) of a 20-week supervised research internship based on an individual research project supervised by a member of academic staff. The project may encompass a systematic literature review, resource or project development, or a clinical or laboratory investigation. The project may also involve a ‘placement’, possibly outside UNSW, in research or industry, which may occur outside session. The course will develop your ability to formulate research questions, conduct in-depth studies, analyse and present data, and write reports.


This course is restricted to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Exercise Physiology 3871.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"770f3550dbb6d010eb6b147a3a961946","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Dissemination Strategy","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

Important research findings are often poorly translated into clinical practice. The assessment task are to:

\n
  • Identify key stakeholders for dissemination of findings of research project
  • Determine strategies for dissemination of results to aid translation of findings into practice
  • Write a 200 word summary of the project, it’s findings and its relevance to the key target audience in language appropriate to the audience
\n

Due in Week 3

This course is the second term (10 weeks) of a 20-week supervised research internship based on an individual research project supervised by a member of academic staff. The project may encompass a systematic literature review, resource or project development, or a clinical or laboratory investigation. The project may also involve a ‘placement’, possibly outside UNSW, in research or industry, which may occur outside session. The course will develop your ability to formulate research questions, conduct in-depth studies, analyse and present data, and write reports.

This course is restricted to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Exercise Physiology 3871.

Provide critical reflection on their clinical placement via an online form targeted at reflecting on professional aspects of the placement including staff developement opportunities, work environment and points for improvement.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"ef02244ddb20fc10fe4b322af496190d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0812644ddb20fc10fe4b322af4961946","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"viva exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

The viva is a practical exam, performed individually by each student for one clinical scenario/case study. Students will be provided a list of assessable skills for their case study, which will be randomly assigned to each student on the day of the viva exam. These skills will be drawn from the clinical competencies and skills/knowledge attained from prior courses. Students will be required to physically perform the appropriate practical skills (exercise testing and communication) and then verbally justify the use of the test in front of an examiner. Students must achieve satisfactory performance in all tasks (pass mark =  70%).

If a student receives 65-69%, their supervisor reports and competency checks from the term will be revisited. If all reports and competencies from the term indicate a Pass (P) grade, they will be eligible to pass the course. Unsatisfactory reports and/or competencies will result in the student failing the course.

If a student receives <65% for the viva assessment they will fail the course .

Keep a log of all practical hours completed in the course. Each record must provide enough detail regarding i) patient presentation ?(pathology, co-morbidities, medications); ii) assessments ?(anthropometry, functional), exercises or activities conducted with the patient; iii) patient response to exercises/activities & ?iv) plans for future session?(s). Students will be given examples of expected structure and will be asked to log their hours an electronic workbook. Logbook entries will be submitted at early, mid-way point and at the end of the practicum term. Formative feedback will be provided after the logbooks are submitted and students may use this feedback to improve future entries.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a302644ddb20fc10fe4b322af4961914","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ab02644ddb20fc10fe4b322af4961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ab02644ddb20fc10fe4b322af4961914","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e702244ddb20fc10fe4b322af496190d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"eb02244ddb20fc10fe4b322af496190c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8412644ddb20fc10fe4b322af4961933","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Practicum Skills Portfolio Part 2: Clinical Competencies Assessment","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

Master practical skills via the Clinical Competency Checklist. This is a checklist of industry standard skills which students will develop throughout the practical components of this course. Competencies will be assessed by practicum supervisors over the term and students must successfully complete a  minimum 3/10 clinical competencies (remaining competencies will be assessed in the subsequent course HESC4622). Students' clinical and professional skills are also evaluated by their Supervisor who submits a brief evaluation report to the Practicum Coordinator. This will be submitted within the final week of the placement.  Students must successfully achieve pass grades in a minimum 3/10 competency checks in addition to satisfactory supervisor reports to pass the course. The Practicum Coordinator and the academic staff will review these reports and will contact students to discuss any unsatisfactory elements.

contentlets.description:
This course will provide you with an opportunity to consolidate and extend clinical skills through supervised placements in the workplace. A minimum of 200 hours of clinical practical experience will be completed within a clinical environment. This is done under the supervision of an accredited exercise physiologist. These practicum hours are a requirement of the accrediting professional body. Performance is monitored through workplace competencies, a VIVA exam, supervisor report and self-reflection.

This course is restricted to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Exercise Physiology 3871.

The Objective Structured Clinical Exam (OSCE) is an authentic performance exam designed to assess students’ abilities in performing various practical skills commonly used in exercise physiology. The assessment environment will simulate multiple clinical scenarios, each involving interaction between the student and simulated client/patient. Each student will be required to perform a range of competencies with a simulated client/patient under the supervision of an examiner. Students will be assessed on communication, technical and procedural skills. Students are required to achieve a minimum of 70% to pass this assessment.

\n

If a student receives 65-69%, their supervisor reports and competency checks from the term will be revisited. If all reports and competencies from the term indicate a Pass (P) grade, they will be eligible to pass the course. Unsatisfactory reports and/or competencies will result in the student failing the course 

\n

If a student receives <65% for the OSCE assessment, they will fail the course.

Master practical skills via the Clinical Competency Checklist. This is a checklist of industry standard skills which students will develop throughout the practical components of this course. Competencies will be assessed by practicum supervisors over the term and students must achieve a minimum Pass grade in the remaining 7/10 clinical competencies (minimum 3/10 competencies completed in prerequisite course HESC4611). Students' clinical and professional skills are also evaluated by their Supervisor who submits a brief evaluation report to the Practicum Coordinator. This will be submitted within the final week of the placement.  Students must successfully achieve pass grades in a minimum 7/10 competency checks in addition to satisfactory supervisor reports to pass the course. The Practicum Coordinator and the academic staff will review these reports and will contact students to discuss any unsatisfactory elements.

contentlets.description:
This course will provide you with an opportunity to consolidate and extend clinical skills through supervised placements in the workplace. A minimum of 200 hours of clinical practical experience will be completed within a clinical environment. This is done under the supervision of an accredited exercise physiologist. These practicum hours are a requirement of the accrediting professional body. Performance is monitored through workplace competencies, supervisor report and an Objective Structured Clinical Exam (OSCE).  

This course is restricted to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Exercise Physiology 3871.
contentlets.title: Clinical Practicum B
